Ian Badcoe wrote:

>Hi,
>	Is there any advice people have to offer if I'm going to start some 
>serious NEAT coding?
>  
>
>	I want to work in C++ on Windows, but I'll probably want to stay away from 
>platform specific issues like user interfaces and graphics output, so I'm 
>pretty confident I can keep away from nasty build problems and suchlike 
>arising from those.
>  
>
Ok I'm going to put in my 2cents worth on  Java/.Net  now so some may 
want to tune to another station for 5 mins :)

A few key points then:
1) C++, Java and C# are syntactially almost identical. If you can code 
in C++ you can do the other two. C# even has pointers.

2) Nasty build problems are largely elminated by Java/.Net - if you get 
the correct JDK/framework version you're almost there. In fact with 
SharpNEAT there are no external dependencies outside of the cour 
library. I'm not 100% sure if this is true of the Java NEATs, but I 
don't recall having any problem building ANJI a while back.

3) .Net is language agnostic and there exist, amongst many others, 
compilers for Java, C++ and C# that target the .Net CLR (The equivalent 
of the Java Virtual Machine). Classes can be definend in one language, 
sub-classed in another and instantiated in yet another, it's so easy I 
felt like crying when I first used it, surely it must be a trick? :)

So you could write an experiment in C++ and plug it into SharpNEAT. On 
the other hand with a few minor syntactic alterations your C++ will 
compile as Java and you can plug it into ANJI - obviously how you attach 
an experiment to our frameworks differs a bit, but not by much I would 
expect.

>	My coding style tends towards object-based approaches, templated 
>utilities, small classes, inheritance only for clearly defined interfaces, 
>STL containers (but not generally streams), lots of asserts and code 
>designed to crash rather than vaguely paper over errors....
>  
>
Java has an assert keyword, .Net just has a Debug.Assert method in the 
framework. But since they run in managed runtime environments you won't 
get any nasty pointer errors, corruption of memory or anything like that 
anyway.

> OTOH, I would be quite happy to start with a written 
>specification and write it myself.  I find this is usually the fastest way 
>to get into understanding all the dirty details...
>  
>
Yeh, absolutely agree there.

>	What do people recommend?
>  
>
Well obviously I'm biased so all I will say is that if you do want to 
try out SharpNEAT then all you need is the SDK from microsoft (free 
download). On top of that you really want a nice IDE and SharpDevelop 
should do nicely there(again, free) - it has support for C++ coding as 
well as C# and others. The only other issue is that there has been 
another code re-org since the version on sourceforge and I've been 
handing out versions to people as and when requested until I get round 
to doing a proper release. The re-org was specifically done to support 
co-ev experiments!

For ANJI you need the Java SDK (free!) and for a free IDE I would 
suggest IBM Eclipse. Actually Eclipse has support for and is integrated 
with all kinds of systems these days, e.g. I strongly suspect you could 
use it for developing in C++ and C# as well.

Colin
